title-group.article-title: Systematic investigation and optimization of fine cotton yarns produced in a modified ring spinning system using statistical methods

abstract.p: A modified ring spinning technique has been recently developed by incorporating false twisting devices into a conventional ring frame for producing a low torque and soft handle singles yarn. Our previous studies showed that this technology can be applied for producing coarse modified yarns (7–32 Ne) with improved yarn and fabric performance. The present paper extends the work for the production and optimization of modified yarns at a fine yarn count (80 Ne). Compared with the conventional ring spinning system, the modified system presents a different and complicated spinning condition in terms of yarn tension and twist distributions, as well as the interaction between the false twisting device and conventional ring frame. Therefore, this paper aims to systematically investigate the quantitative relationship between spinning system parameters and physical properties of the fine modified yarns using the combined statistical methods of fractional factorial and response surface methodology. In this paper, potential spinning system parameters are proposed and the significances of their effect on yarn properties are quantitatively evaluated. Then the statistical relationships between the significant system parameters and the properties of fine modified yarn are fully examined and optimized. With these optimum parameters, the fine modified yarn and woven fabric were produced and their properties were assessed and compared with the conventional ones.

body.p: Ring spinning is one of the most widely used spinning techniques for processing staple fibers in the textile industry. Over the past few decades, many new developments have been made in order to improve yarn quality. Notable ones include compact spinning,1,2 siro spinning3,4 and solo spinning.5,6 All these novel spinning techniques incorporate particular modification components into the conventional spinning system for the development of improved or novel yarn features. Some other novel modifications have been developed to improve yarn properties7,8 and a number of theoretical modelings related to yarn dynamic behavior have been carried out for the analysis.9–12

Recently, a modified spinning technique has been developed for producing a low torque and soft handle singles ring yarn by incorporating the false twisting device into a conventional spinning frame.13,14 Our previous studies demonstrated that the modified spinning technique has been successfully applied for the production of coarse cotton yarns (7–32 Ne) with improved yarn and fabric performance.15–21 Also in the modified spinning system, with the incorporation of false twisting device, the spun yarn will perform a different dynamic behavior from the yarn produced in a conventional spinning system.21–23 However, application of the modified spinning technique on fine count cotton yarns has not been explored. Compared with the coarse yarn counts, there may be some difficulties for the fine modified yarn in controlling the variation of yarn properties and spinnability, because of the low yarn strength and the decreased effectiveness of fiber migration when only a small number of fibers are present inside the yarn. More recently, our feasibility study24 revealed that the modified spinning technique can be applicable to fine cotton yarns with machine modifications. Preliminary results showed that fine modified yarns have some advantages in terms of yarn tenacity and hairiness when compared with conventional yarns.

Therefore, in this paper, a systematic study is carried out to fully examine the significance and quantitative relationships between various spinning systems’ parameters and physical properties of the fine modified cotton yarns (80 Ne). Firstly, system parameters of the modified spinning system, which have significant influences on yarn properties, were identified and then systematically examined using statistical methods of fractional factorial and response surface methodology. Then, individual effects of the significant parameters on the properties of fine modified yarn were quantitatively investigated for optimization of the modified yarns. Finally, with the optimized parameters, the modified yarns and woven fabric were produced and their properties were assessed and compared with the conventional ones.

sec.title: Spinning process of the modified yarn
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows a schematic view of the modified spinning system. Compared with the conventional spinning system, a modification unit, namely a false twisting device, is installed on the conventional ring frame. In the system, after passing through a front pair of rollers, a strand of drafted roving fibers is twisted together by the false twist generated by the false twisting device, forming a preliminary single yarn. Immediately after leaving the false twisting device, the preliminary single yarn is reversely twisted as a resultant of the false twist and the real twist propagated from the traveler, forming a final single yarn. The final yarn passes through the yarn guide and traveler and finally is wound onto a rotating package centered in a ring spindle. Figure 1.
Schematic view of the modified ring spinning system.

In the modified spinning system, the incorporation of the false twisting device modifies the spinning geometry of the conventional ring frame, leading to different and complicated distributions of yarn twist and spinning tension.21–23 Firstly, false twist is generated by the false twisting device for twisting the drafted fibers and it interacts with true twist from the traveler. Secondly, due to mechanical contacts between spun yarn and false twisting device, a large number of friction forces are generated, so relatively larger tension forces are required to overcome these forces in order to pull the highly twisted yarn out of the false twisting device.14,24 Finally, the spatial position of the false twisting device and relevant modification parameters may also have potential influences on the dynamic behavior and spinnability of the modified yarns.

Therefore, compared with the conventional spinning method, more system parameters should be considered for the modified system. These may include the interaction between false twist and true twist, the spinning tension-related component and spatial position and relevant modification parameters of the false twisting device. The first parameter, speed ratio, which is defined as the speed ratio of the false twisting device to the ring spindle,14,15 can be used to quantify the linkage between the false twist and true twist. The magnitudes of the speed ratio determine the number of false twists inserted into spun yarn relative to the true twist. For the second parameter, traveler weight can be adopted as a key parameter in influencing yarn tension. The magnitudes of the traveler weight influence the spinning tension and twist distributions along the modified yarn path, which in turn influences the spinning process and the physical properties of the modified yarn. For the last type of parameters, the spatial position of the false twisting device modifies the yarn path in the modified spinning system, which affects the contacting angle and contacting length between the spun yarn and false twisting device, and thus may influence the smoothness of the spinning process. The contacting angle and contacting length are associated with the angle formed by the entry of spun yarn into the false twisting device with the horizontal base line and the length of spun yarn over the false twisting device, respectively.

Based on the above discussions, the modified system presents a different and complicated spinning condition from the conventional ring frame, so it is necessary to carry out a systematic study for investigating the effects of potential system parameters on the modified yarn properties. Therefore, in the following section, combined statistical methods of the fractional factorial and response surface methodology are adopted for the analysis. Besides the conventional parameter of the twist multiplier, other parameters, such as speed ratio, weight of traveler, contacting angle and contacting length, are selected as the potential parameters. The fractional factorial method was used to analyze the effect significance of the above-mentioned five parameters on yarn properties. The significant influential parameters were then identified and optimized with the response surface methodology and their individual influences on yarn properties were also quantitatively examined.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
In this experiment, combed roving of 332 tex (1.78 Ne), with a measured coefficient of variation of 4.32% (Uster), was used as the raw material. The fiber properties were tested on the Spinlab 900; the results are shown in Table 1. Table 1.
Specifications of cotton fiber
Fiber length (inch) 1.475
Uniformity ratio (%) 54.53
Fiber strength (g/tex) 32.50
Elongation (%) 6.53
Micronaire value 4.25

A Zinser 351 spinning machine with false twisting devices installed was employed for the production of 80 Ne modified cotton yarns. Five cop samples were prepared and employed for each testing. All cop yarn samples were conditioned under standard conditions at 20 ± 2° and 65 ± 2% relative humidity (RH) for at least 24 hours before testing. Yarn strength, snarling tendency, evenness and hairiness are the most concerned properties of the modified yarns. Yarn snarling is used to indicate the level of residual torque of yarn and measured as the number of wet yarn snarls per 25 cm by a yarn snarling testing apparatus.25–27 Ten readings were recorded for each type of yarn. Yarn strength and breaking elongation were obtained on the Uster Tensorapid tester. Fifty readings were obtained for each sample, with a testing length of 500 mm and testing speed of 5000 mm/min. Yarn evenness was measured on the Uster III tester. Each sample was measured at a testing speed of 400 m/min for 2.5 minutes. A Zweigle hairiness tester was used for the measurement of hairiness. Three readings were adopted and averaged for each sample, at a testing speed of 100 m/min.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The experiment analysis was designed by using a statistical method combining the fractional factorial and response surface design.28,29 The fractional factorial design is used to identify which parameters are likely to have significant influences on yarn properties, by carrying out a fraction of the experimental runs of a full factorial design. Then the parameters with significant influences are optimized following a sequence of experiments obtained from the response surface design to search the optimum region for different requirements.

Based on the above discussions, five spinning parameters were selected as independent variables, with the physical properties of modified yarn as dependent output response variables. Since a relatively large number of factors are required to be investigated, the number of runs (25 = 32) required for sampling a complete replicate greatly outgrows the resource of the experiment. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct the fractional factorial experiment in the first-stage experiment in order to eliminate the unimportant variables so that subsequent experiments will be more sufficient and require fewer runs. In this experiment, in order to obtain more accurate information on the interactive relationships among the parameters, a half fraction of five factors at two levels (25–1) of factorial experiments with 16 runs was carried out to identify those most likely to be critical for subsequent experiments. Table 2 shows the levels of the five independent variables in the fractional factorial experiment, which covers a wide range of operating parameters in the modified spinning system. Table 2.

sec.title: Analysis of the fractional factorial experiment
sec.p:
According to the fractional factorial experiment, properties of the fine modified yarns were measured and the effects of twist multiplier, speed ratio, weight of traveler, contacting angle and contacting length on the properties of modified yarns are as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Significance of effects of the five parameters on yarn properties (where A = twist multiplier, B = speed ratio, C = weight of the traveler, D = contacting angle, E = contacting length): (a) yarn tenacity; (b) yarn snarling; (c) yarn hairiness; (d) yarn evenness.

It is clear from Figure 2 that, generally, the twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of traveler have statistically significant influences on the properties of modified yarn at a significant level of 0.05, while the other two factors of contacting angle and contacting length show no significant influences. As shown in Figure 2(a), the tenacity of the modified yarn is greatly influenced by the weight of the traveler, followed by the twist multiplier and speed ratio. Also, the interaction between the twist multiplier and speed ratio (AB) shows significant influences on yarn tenacity and is statistically more important than the speed ratio. In Figure 2(b), it is demonstrated that yarn snarling is more influenced by the twist multiplier when compared with the speed ratio and weight of the traveler. Also, the interactions between the speed ratio and contacting angle (BD), the contacting angle and contacting length (DE), weight of traveler and contacting angle (CD) and weight of traveler and contacting length (CE) show some statistically significant influences on yarn snarling. In Figure 2(c), the twist multiplier is the most influential parameter on yarn hairiness in the modified spinning system. Evenness of the modified yarn is mainly affected by the speed ratio, as presented in Figure 2(d).

Figure 3 shows the trend of yarn properties with the changes of twist multiplier, speed ratio, weight of traveler, contacting angle and length of the false twisting device. In Figure 3(a), it can be seen that yarn tenacity rapidly increases with the increase of the twist multiplier and weight of traveler and slightly decreases with the increase of the speed ratio. In Figures 3(b) and (c), it is noted that as the twist multiplier increases, yarn hairiness is considerably reduced, and on the contrary, there is a great increase in yarn snarling. Also, it can be seen in Figure 3(b) that higher speed ratios and heavier travelers can result in less yarn snarling. Figure 3(d) shows that the increase of speed ratio and twist multiplier and the decrease of traveler weight can improve yarn evenness. Figure 3.
The trend of effects of the five parameters on yarn properties (where A = twist multiplier, B = speed ratio, C = weight of the traveler, D = contacting angle, E = contacting length): (a) yarn tenacity; (b) yarn snarling; (c) yarn hairiness; (d) yarn evenness.

sec.title: Analysis of the response surface experiment
sec.p: Based on the above analysis, the twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of the traveler are identified as significant influential parameters on the properties of fine modified yarns. Thus, these three significant parameters were chosen for subsequent investigation using the response surface design to examine the actual relationships with yarn properties.

sec.title: Effects on yarn tenacity
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the effects of twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of traveler on tenacity of the fine modified yarns. Figure 4.
Effect of the three significant parameters on the tenacity of fine modified yarn (the numbers 3.9 and 0.725 are the mean values of the twist multiplier and speed ratio, respectively). (a) Effects of speed ratio and weight of the traveler at the twist multiplier of 3.9. (b) Effects of twist multiplier and weight of the traveler at the speed ratio of 0.725.

As shown in Figure 4(a), it can be found that yarn tenacity goes up with the decreased speed ratio at the twist multiplier of 3.9. Higher yarn tenacity could be achieved when using lower speed ratios and heavier travelers. In Figure 4(b), an obvious trend can be observed that yarn tenacity increases with the increase in twist multiplier at the speed ratio of 0.725. With higher weights of traveler, a larger increase in yarn tenacity is presented.

In addition, it can be clearly seen that the weight of the traveler has a larger influence on yarn tenacity than the twist multiplier and speed ratio. As the weight of the traveler increases, yarn tenacity apparently increases, especially in the region of lower speed ratios and higher twists. This somehow contradicts the situation of the conventional spinning system in that the twist has a greater influence on yarn tenacity than the other spinning parameters.

The great improvement in yarn tenacity can be attributed to the modification of yarn structure. As indicated by the structural analysis on the coarser yarns,17–19 it was found that the modified yarn shows a much higher packing density near the yarn axis, which results in a more compact structure of the modified yarn, potentially enhancing yarn strength by the lateral pressure between fibers. Also, the unique characteristics of the modified yarns, such as deformed non-concentric helices and some knots, increase the frictional contact between fibers, reducing the fiber slippage during the occurrence of yarn breakage, thus improving yarn strength. In addition, the modified yarn possesses much lower inclination angles, which increases the force component in the direction of yarn extension, reducing the chance of non-simultaneity during the occurrence of yarn rupture, thus contributing to yarn strength. These structural analyses will be extended to finer yarn counts and reported in the future.

sec.title: Effects on yarn snarling
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the effects of the twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of the traveler on the snarling of fine modified yarns. Figure 5.
Effect of the three significant parameters on the snarling of fine modified yarn (the numbers 3.9 and 0.725 are the mean values of the twist multiplier and speed ratio, respectively). (a) Effects of speed ratio and weight of the traveler at the twist multiplier of 3.9. (b) Effects of twist multiplier and weight of the traveler at the speed ratio of 0.725.

As shown in Figure 5, it is obvious that the twist multiplier has a greater influence on yarn snarling than the speed ratio and weight of the traveler. In Figure 5(b), as the twist multiplier increases, there is an almost linear increase in yarn snarling at the speed ratio of 0.725. Lower twist multipliers and heavier travelers can result in lower yarn snarling. This is because when the twist is inserted into spun yarn, yarn torque is immediately generated and then follows a gradual increase with the increase of yarn twist.30 Figure 5(a) clearly demonstrated that the traveler weight has a non-linear relationship with yarn snarling at the twist multiplier of 3.9, and it is also observed that there is no appreciable change in yarn snarling with the changes of speed ratio.

sec.title: Effects on yarn hairiness
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows the effects of the twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of the traveler on the hairiness of fine modified yarns. It is clearly shown that the relationship between the twist multiplier and yarn hairiness is almost linear at the speed ratio of 0.725, which is similar to conventional yarn. Compared with other factors, the twist multiplier has the greatest influence on yarn hairiness. Also from Figure 6, it is clear that the weight of the traveler has much less influence on yarn hairiness, and speed ratio presents a non-linear relationship with yarn hairiness. Figure 6.
Effect of the three significant parameters on the hairiness of fine modified yarn (the numbers 3.9 and 0.725 are the mean values of the twist multiplier and speed ratio, respectively). (a) Effects of speed ratio and weight of the traveler at the twist multiplier of 3.9. (b) Effects of twist multiplier and weight of the traveler at the speed ratio of 0.725.

sec.title: Effects on yarn evenness
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows the effects of the twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of the traveler on the evenness of fine modified yarns. Figure 7.
Effect of the three significant parameters on the evenness of fine modified yarn (the numbers 3.9 and 0.725 are the mean values of the twist multiplier and speed ratio, respectively). (a) Effects of speed ratio and weight of the traveler at the twist multiplier of 3.9. (b) Effects of twist multiplier and weight of the traveler at the speed ratio of 0.725.

It is clear from Figure 7 that the speed ratio has a larger influence on yarn evenness than the other factors. As the speed ratio increases, yarn evenness becomes better in the region of lower weights of the traveler, while a non-linear relationship is presented with higher weights of the traveler at the twist multiplier of 3.9. The higher speed ratios and lighter travelers can lead to the reduction of yarn unevenness. Also, as shown in Figure 7(b), with lower weights of the traveler, the increase in twist multiplier can result in better yarn evenness at the speed ratio of 0.725. However, yarn evenness becomes worse in the region of higher weights of the traveler.

sec.title: Optimization of yarn properties
sec.p: In this paper, yarn tenacity is the major concern in evaluating the performance of finer modified yarns. The other properties, such as yarn hairiness, snarling and evenness, should meet the requirements of relevant yarn qualities. Therefore, one useful approach, namely overlaid contour plots, was adopted to identify the optimized combination of the three significant parameters for obtaining the desired properties of finer modified yarns.

Based on the investigation of fractional factorial and response surface experiments, it can be found that the weight of the traveler is one of the key factors in influencing the tenacity of fine modified yarns. In general, a heavier traveler tends to increase the tenacity of modified yarns. Thus, the weight of the traveler is set at a high level to obtain good yarn strength. The overlaid contour plot is then employed to further optimize the other two spinning parameters. Before the analysis, the lower boundary and upper boundary of each yarn property are required to be set at desired levels. As an example, yarn tenacity was set for over 27cN/tex. Yarn evenness was lower than 15.2%, followed by yarn hairiness and snarling with their bounds of 0–70 and 0–100 turns/25 cm, respectively. With these settings, the overlaid contour plot of each yarn property can be calculated and is shown in Figure 8. Figure 8.
The overlaid contour plot of yarn properties.

In Figure 8, the white zone is the feasible region in which any combination of spinning parameters is capable of obtaining the desired yarn properties. Based on the optimization plot, a set of optimized parameters could be found and then used for producing yarns with the desirable yarn properties. As seen from Table 5, for tenacity and evenness of modified cop yarn, the measured values were very close to their estimated values and the errors were 0.7% and 2.7%, respectively. The estimation error of yarn snarling was about 10.3%. However, the measured hairiness S3 value was obviously lower than the estimated values by 22.5%.

Table 6 shows the comparison results of the cone yarn property after winding between finer modified and conventional yarns produced with the same fiber material and twist multiplier. It is clear that the modified cone yarns have much better yarn tenacity and hairiness than the conventional yarns. The significant t-test in the same table shows that the difference for all properties between the two yarns is statistically significant. The tenacity of the modified yarn is significantly increased by over 18.6% and the hairiness is greatly reduced by 55.5%. In addition, yarn snarling of modified yarn is reduced by 8.3%, from 104.2 turns/25 cm to 95.5 turns/25 cm. However, the elongation of the modified yarn shows a large reduction by 35.3% from 4.48% to 2.90%. The evenness of finer modified yarn becomes slightly worse by 3.5% and the total imperfection indicated as an IPI value has a considerable increase from 128 to 330. IPI is the imperfection index, which is the sum of thin places (−50%)/km, thick places (+50%)/km and neps (+200%)/km. Our further investigation indicated that this is mainly due to sliding frictional contacts between the spun yarn and false twisting device caused by higher tension, which results in an increased yarn irregularity. Therefore, improvement on the modified spinning system has been being made and the experimental results indicated some notable improvements in yarn evenness and imperfection, which will be reported in the future. sec.title: Comparison of fabric properties
sec.p:

Thus, in this section, two types of fabric made from 80 Ne conventional and modified yarns (see Table 6) are fabricated in a factory with the same fabric structure and weaving machine; their specifications are shown in Table 7. Five fabric samples made from conventional and modified yarns were prepared. Five readings were obtained and averaged for each type of fabric. All fabric samples were conditioned under standard condition at 20 ± 2° and 65 ± 2% RH for at least 24 hours before testing. The breaking and tearing strength of fabrics were measured on the Instron tester and Elmatear with ASTM D5034 and ASTM D1424 the standards, respectively. A Universal Wear Tester was used for the measurement of fabric abrasion according to the ASTM D3885 standard. As clearly shown in Table 8, when woven into fabric, the modified yarns as warp and weft yarns have better performance in breaking strength. Compared with the fabric made from conventional yarns, the breaking strength of the fabric made from modified yarns significantly (at a 0.05 significant level) increases by 14.4% and 5.5% in the warp and weft directions, respectively. Also, the fabric made from modified yarns shows much better tearing strength in the weft direction, which significantly (at a 0.05 significant level) increases by 22.6%. This improvement in fabric breaking and tearing strength can be explained by the increased strength of modified yarn (see Table 6). Also, the abrasion of fabric produced by modified yarns greatly (at a 0.1 significant level) increases, with an improvement of 16.1% and 17.2% in warp and weft yarns, respectively.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the system parameters of fine cotton yarns produced in a modified spinning system were systematically investigated and optimized with combined statistical methods of fractional factorial and response surface methodology. Compared with the conventional spinning system, the modified spinning system performs different and complicated relationships between system parameters and yarn properties. The analysis of the fractional factorial experiment indicated that the twist multiplier, speed ratio and weight of the traveler have significant influences on the properties of fine modified yarns. Their quantitative relationships were fully examined by using the response surface method and explicitly formulated by the response surface equations with higher levels of coefficient correlation.

Analysis of response surface plots showed that the speed ratio and traveler weight show larger influences on yarn evenness and tenacity, respectively, while yarn snarling and hairiness are more influenced by the twist multiplier. The speed ratio presents a non-linear relationship with yarn hairiness. When compared with conventional ring yarns, modified yarns show significantly improved yarn tenacity, hairiness and yarn snarling. As a result, woven fabrics made from modified yarns show improved breaking strength, abrasion resistance and tearing strength.
